snippet: If no pension deal can be reached by November of next year, when the city will draft its next budget, Chicago will either have to raise taxes or cut services or some combination of both.
abstract: Chicago is pursuing deal to relieve its staggering pension systems on heels of Illinois passing landmark bill to trim retirement benefits for state workers; under state law, city must increase its contributions to its workers' pensions funds by $590 million in 2015; Mayor Rahm Emanuel says that if no deal is reached by November 2014, when city drafts its next budget, it will be forced to raise taxes or cut services or some combination of both.

byline.contributor: Steven Yaccino contributed reporting from Chicago.

lead_paragraph: If no pension deal can be reached by November of next year, when the city will draft its next budget, Chicago will either have to raise taxes or cut services or some combination of both.

headline.main: Chicago Pursues Deal to Change Pension Funding
headline.print_headline: Chicago Pursues Deal to Change Pension Funding
